channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Taliban Confirm Death of Mullah Omar and Weigh Successor
item.description: The insurgent group is mulling its future after the death of its leader and deciding whether to keep trying to engage in talks with the Afghan government.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghans watched news about peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government at a cafe in Kabul in 2013. The Taliban on Thursday confirmed the death of their supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar.

item.title: Myanmar Frees Loggers From China Amid a Broader Amnesty
item.description: After a strong pushback from Beijing, more than 150 citizens who were sentenced to life in prison were suddenly released.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.media:description: The journalist Min Wa Than, center, was greeted by his sister and father on Thursday after being released from prison in Yangon, Myanmar, as part of an amnesty that included more than 150 Chinese loggers.

item.title: India Executes Yakub Memon, Man Tied to 1993 Mumbai Bombings
item.description: India’s news media has been stirred by a robust debate over whether Yakub Memon, a Muslim in this predominantly Hindu nation, deserved to die.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:description: Demonstrations this week in support of the execution of Yakub Memon for his role in bombings in Mumbai.

item.title: Vietnam Floods Kill 17 and Threaten to Pollute Ha Long Bay
item.description: Environmental groups said that waste from coal mines could damage the northern bay, a Unesco World Heritage site famous for its steep limestone islands.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Searching the site of a landslide caused by heavy rain in Ha Long, Vietnam, on Tuesday.

item.title: Landslides in Western Nepal Leave at Least 24 Dead
item.description: Several villages in the popular tourist area of Kaski were hit, and the death toll could rise, an official said.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Wariness Over Link Between Debris in Réunion and Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
item.description: Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss of Australia, whose country has led the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, said only that the discovery was “a major lead.”
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Police officers inspecting a piece of debris on Wednesday that appeared to be an airplane part found on the western Indian Ocean island of Réunion.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What I Learned on Stage
item.description: Writing and acting in a play helped me see the promise and limits of journalism.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Tiananmen Square Pops Up Ahead of Military Parade
item.description: Tight security surrounds the rehearsal grounds for a military parade, as nearby restaurants sit empty and factories are ordered closed.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Wu Hao, Sina News
item.media:description: A replica of Tiananmen Square on the outskirts of Beijing. The site is being used for the rehearsals of the Sept. 3 military parade marking the end of World War II.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ai Weiwei Disputes Restricted Visa From Britain
item.description: The artist, who was detained for 81 days in 2011, disagrees with British officials over whether he has a criminal conviction and says the visa he received may keep him from attending his installation in London.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Ai Weiwei placing flowers in a bicycle basket outside his Beijing studio on Dec. 30, 2013, as a protest against restrictions on his travel.

item.title: Mexican President’s Ties to Contractor Raise Questions
item.description: Several recent scandals have tainted the legacy of President Enrique Peña Nieto and further eroded the public’s faith in the country’s governing institutions.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parts of a protected forest in Xochicuautla, Mexico, have been cut, exposing the path of a highway that is demolishing areas of an indigenous community.

item.title: Debris Is Thought to Come From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
item.description: U.S. investigators concluded that an object that washed up on the shore of Réunion, an island in the Indian Ocean, came from a Boeing 777, making it likely that it was from the flight that vanished in 2014.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN, NICOLA CLARK and CHRISTOPHER DREW
item.media:description: Police officers carried a piece of debris that appeared to be an airplane part found on Réunion, a French island in the western Indian Ocean.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Seeking a Middle Path in Hong Kong Politics
item.description: The Liberal Party is trying to attract young Hong Kong voters with a message that’s warm to pro-democracy activists and to Beijing.
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The Levels club in Lan Kwai Fong, where the Liberal Party held a gathering for younger Hong Kongers.

item.title: India Executes Yakub Memon, Man Tied to 1993 Mumbai Bombings
item.description: India’s news media has been stirred by a robust debate over whether Yakub Memon, a Muslim in this predominantly Hindu nation, deserved to die.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:description: Demonstrations this week in support of the execution of Yakub Memon for his role in bombings in Mumbai.

item.title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Tribunal for Malaysia Airlines Crash in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had called the effort to investigate the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 “untimely and counterproductive."
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local men building a monument two weeks ago at one of the crash sites where the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed last year in Hrabovo, in the rebel controlled eastern Ukraine.

item.title: India Hangs Yakub Memom, Convicted of 1993 Mumbai Bombings
item.description: India hanged Yakub Memon on Thursday for his role in the country's deadliest bomb attacks that killed at least 257 people in Mumbai in 1993, two Indian television channels reported.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Demonstrations this week opposed to the execution.

item.title: India Will Be Most Populous Country Sooner Than Thought, U.N. Says
item.description: India’s population was expected to surpass China’s by 2022, not 2028 as it had previously forecast.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Maldahiyya basti, a colony of families in Varanasi, India, last year.

item.title: Killer of Cecil the Lion Finds Out That He Is a Target Now, of Internet Vigilantism
item.description: Dr. Walter J. Palmer, the hunter who killed Cecil after he was lured out of his sanctuary at Hwange National Park in Zimbabwe, has faced an onslaught from social media users and online reviewers.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CAPECCHI and KATIE ROGERS
item.media:credit: Renee Jones Schneider/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A memorial to Cecil the lion outside Dr. Walter J. Palmer's closed dental office in Bloomington, Minn.

item.title: Top General Gives ‘Pragmatic’ View of Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Senate committee that the diplomatic approach to relieving the risk of a nuclear conflict was the right one.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Senators John McCain and Jack Reed spoke to Energy Secretary Ernest J. Moniz, right, after a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on Wednesday.

item.title: Outlook for the Ex-Im Bank Dims as Congress Departs
item.description: Republicans who would cheer the end of the bank see the failure to reauthorize it before the August recess as a near guarantee of success.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Labour’s Reckless Left Turn
item.description: Electing a veteran socialist as leader would make the party irrelevant in British politics.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA
